column4: Oy, is there any sort of resource that is the equivalent of 'So, you've finally decided to tell Microsoft where to stick it...here's how to use Ubuntu.'?
just download a LiveCD and boot your computer off it, don't have to install Ubuntu to try it out, just boot off the LiveCD
I've got it installed and running, and I can tinker with it, but I'm looking for a guide of some sort.
It depends on what you want to do with it.  What do you want to do?
I want to know how the file system works, how to fix corrupted/crashing programs (I know how to install them, but when they start crashing out I'm SOL), etc.  Just a general 'here's how'.
fixing filesystems is the fsck command.  Fixing crashed programs...
I think what I do for that is just to google for any error message that comes up when a program crashes.
I ended up having to reinstal ubuntu completely
If you're pretty newb, I'd try to make sure not to get too deep into stuff.  It's lots more fun to learn if you just do it piece by piece and don't try to dive down into the depths too quickly.
Sorry, I explained but forgot to tag your name.  Prog kept dying, in terminal it said 'core dumped' and I tried to uninstall/reinstall, but it continued to do the same.
To correct it, I ended up reinstalling ubuntu completely.
What program was it?  What repository did you install it from?

What I've done, is when problems like that come up, I just get on the internet and figure out what the problem is when you've got the problem.  That's how most people learn.  You probably could have learned something about fixing it in the time it took you to reinstall?
Xchat, and I'm not sure which it came from.  Behold, I am n00b.
As a newb, I'd really just stick to the Canonical repositories.  XChat is in Canonical.
